prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the scenario is in the wrong. The situation is about a husband setting up his office in the bedroom, leading to conflicts because the wife can't use the space freely.

First, the husband moved his office to the bedroom instead of the basement where it would be quieter. The wife has to manage the kids and household tasks, and his office placement is causing her significant inconvenience. She suggested the basement, which he rejected for the view. Now, she's not keeping him undisturbed, which he expects because of his job setup.

The key points here are about mutual respect and consideration. The husband's choice to place his office in the bedroom seems self-serving, ignoring the wife's needs. By not following her suggestion, he's creating a situation where she can't perform basic tasks. The wife is then trying to balance her work and household duties without being able to do so because of his setup. 

The husband is expecting her to maintain silence and avoid using the top floor, which is a lot to ask, especially since she's also working and managing the kids. If he had chosen the basement as initially suggested, this conflict wouldn't exist. So, the root issue is his decision to prioritize his view over her practical needs. 

The wife's actions are a reaction to his setup. She can't reasonably be expected to restrict her own activities if he's in a common area like the bedroom. Therefore, she's not in the wrong for not keeping him undisturbed because he chose a less optimal location for his office. The responsibility lies more with him for not heeding her advice and creating the conflict in the first place.
